title: 106_hr2053
content: The "Checkoff for Charity Act of 1999" is also known as the "Designation of Overpayments and Contributions for Charity" under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act allows for the designation of overpayments and contributions for charity. Individual taxpayers can designate a portion of their overpayment of tax and any cash contribution included with their return to an eligible organization under the Checkoff for Charity Act of 1999. This designation must be made at the time of filing the tax return and in the manner prescribed by the Secretary. Individual taxpayers can designate a portion of their overpayment of tax to an eligible organization at the time of filing their tax return. The overpayment designated shall be treated as refunded to the taxpayer as of the last date prescribed for filing the return. Part IX. Designation of overpayments and contributions for charity. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 102. CHECKOFF FOR CHARITIES TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section titled "CHECKOFF FOR CHARITIES TRUST FUND." A trust fund called the 'Checkoff for Charities Trust Fund' is established in the Treasury, funded by appropriations or credits. Amounts designated under section 6097 are transferred to the fund. The Secretary pays the Checkoff for Charities Commission from the fund quarterly, minus any administrative expenses. The Checkoff for Charities Trust Fund is used to pay administrative expenses of the Secretary of the Treasury related to modifying tax return forms, carrying out relevant chapters, and processing funds received under section 6097. The "Checkoff for Charity Commission" is established in the Department of Commerce, with duties outlined for the Commission. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. The Checkoff for Charity Commission, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, arranges for voluntary charitable agencies to solicit contributions through tax returns. Contributions are limited to specified organizations and must be paid within 90 days. The Checkoff for Charity Commission arranges for voluntary charitable agencies to solicit contributions through tax returns. Contributions must be paid to the designated organization within 90 days. If amounts are not designated for a specific organization, the Commission may retain one percent for administrative purposes and distribute the rest to eligible organizations based on criteria. The Commission selects organizations based on criteria from Executive Order 12353, amended by Executive Order 12404. SEC. 203. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed by the President, representing diverse groups in the U.S. They must not be affiliated with organizations funded by the Act and no more than 8 members can be from the same political party. Each member serves a six-year term, with exceptions for initial appointees. Appointments can bypass certain limitations on executive positions. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President for staggered terms of two, four, and six years. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members serve without pay, except for full-time federal employees. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President for staggered terms. Members who are full-time federal employees cannot receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. Each member receives travel expenses. Eight members constitute a quorum, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Chairman and Vice Chairman are designated by the President and the Chairman's term is three years. The Commission meets at the call of the Chairman or a majority of its members. SEC. 204. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed without regard to certain regulations, who will be paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional staff as needed, subject to Commission rules. The Director and staff will be appointed under title 5, United States Code, and paid according to relevant provisions. The Director may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 205. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain information from government agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises. The Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property to aid its work. It can use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission also has the power to issue subpoenas. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas, requiring witnesses to testify and produce evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence production. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in court-ordered punishment for civil contempt. Subpoenas must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, and process serving can be done in the judicial district where the person resides or is found. Testimony or evidence cannot be refused based on immunity grounds, except as provided in the subsection. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence in investigations. Individuals can claim the privilege against self-incrimination, but may still be prosecuted for perjury. The Commission is also allowed to contract with government and private agencies for property and services without following certain statutes. The Commission is required to submit an annual report detailing its activities to the Secretary of Commerce and Congress by December 31 each year. Additionally, there is authorization for necessary appropriations for startup costs in the first two fiscal years after the enactment of the Act.
